1. First, we need to define a "drought spell". A drought spell can be considered as a period where no Black actress receives a nomination for at least one year.
2. Next, we need to check the years where there were no nominations for Black actresses. From the table, it appears that from 1960 to 1967 and from 1972 to 1971 (note: there was a nomination in 1973), Black actresses did not receive any nominations.
3. Then, we need to check the length of these drought spells. The first one lasts for 8 years (from 1960 to 1967) and the second one lasts for 2 years (from 1972 to 1971).
4. Finally, we check if there are more than 2 drought spells that last more than 6 years. In this case, only one drought spell lasts more than 6 years (8 years from 1960 to 1967), and there is another one lasting 2 years (from 1972 to 1971).

The claim states "there be more than 2 drought spells span more than 6 year where black actoresses get no nomination". Since only one drought spell lasts more than 6 years, the answer is FALSE.
